comments.text: One thing Maruti really need to work on is car positioning. Owning this good car has a down side of taxi image. Taxi owner do not mind less attractive looks. Old look with new safe chassis should be for taxi ðŸš– and this should be position under next brand something similar like Ertiga & XL6
comments.author: @neelgem8037

comments.text: Maruti marketed this wonderfully, releasing the 5 star rating just before the launch. I wonder what might be the ratings for baleno, fronx etc. Anyways, when the largest car manufacturer in india produces 5 star rated safe cars, it is a win for us the customersðŸŽ‰
comments.author: @surajravindrababu8986

comments.text: I'm happy for the sales people at Arena - one thing that other Indian manufacturers did better is now something Maruti has caught up on as well, you can't gaslight a sales rep at Arena anymore to get discounts, haha. Remember a quote from Rajiv Bajaj where he said one of their product philosophies was around making the job of the sales person at the showroom easier, this resonates with that so well. Good on Maruti, and kudos to their engineers!
comments.author: @1binufrancis

comments.text:
As you mentioned, average buyers would not complain; but as a member of the same group, I would have like some spice up / modernity just like the exterior. And a 5* from Maruti seems like a dream, but it would not boost up sales for sure ( it will still take time and multiple products for Maruti to be branded as a a company which churns out 4-5* rated products).
Kudos to you and PD team to bring up simple and effective review video.
comments.author: @RohitSingh-y1k8i

comments.text:
They can easily sell these easily in the Europe for 15k starting, and it will still be extremely reasonable
Also, Maruti please consider an estate version especially for the CNG cars, in the current cab Dzire, there's no space for even a cabin luggage sized suitcase in the boot space.
comments.author: @c63w204W

videos.description:
Join us on the first drive of the all-new 2024 Maruti Suzuki Dzire, now starting at â‚¹6.79 lakh! With a sharp new design, refreshed interiors, and a fuel-efficient 1.2-litre engine, this Dzire aims to redefine the compact sedan segment. Plus, with its 5-star safety rating, Maruti has raised the bar in safety. In this video, we take the Dzire for a spin to see if it lives up to the hype. Is it worth the price? Find out in our in-depth first drive review!

comments.text:
The one car which has actually improved compared to previous generations. This looks sorted, the front looks premium and the back is passable. Snap in some wider tyres and its a well proportioned car!

A breath of fresh air compared to modern day cars with tubelights at the front and back and headlamps placed at foglamp slots

videos.description:
The 2024 Maruti Suzuki Dzire has arrived as the most anticipated sedan of the year! Ready to take on rivals like the Hyundai Aura and the upcoming Honda Amaze, the new Dzire boasts a fresh, sharper design and stylish updates, with interiors aligned to the 2024 Swift. Under the hood, it carries the same efficient 1.2-litre petrol engine as its hatchback sibling. Join Cyrus Dhabhar in Goa for the first look, and stay tuned for the upcoming full review!

a lot with it the engine the gearbox a lot of the Interior but it does get some exclusive desire bits and today we have it in beautiful Goa to see what it's like out on the road [Music] [Applause] [Music] now the looks obviously the talking point on the desire gone is the bulbous curvy look of the Swift and in place you have a Sleek angular look for the desire it starts off with these phone the instrument cluster is similar to the Swift with the analog dials but on the desire you get a chrome ring around the speedometer as well unlike the Swift which only gets it for the ref counter that's the front let's quickly see what all is new at the rear now in the back seat of the all new desire because there has no change to the wheelbase space is not too different from the Swift knee room is just about enough and the back seat is good enough for two passengers there are three-point seat belts for three passengers but only headrest for two so three in the back will be a bit of interior of the Swift courtesy the bright upholster and bright colored panels all around [Music] the new desire was also crash tested by global encap and has scored a perfect five-star rating for adult occupant protection and four stars for child occupant protection making it the first maruti to get a five-star GN cap safety rating the tests include a frontal offset crash test done at 64 kph a side barrier test done at 50 kph a side pole test and a pedestrian safety test as well clearly maruti has done a lot to distinguish the desire from the Swift but when it comes to the powertrain they both are in the same [Music] boat and that means it gets the same 1.2 L 3-cylinder Z2 e engine 82 horsepower 112 n m and made it to a 5-speed manual and a 5-speed AMT now the latter is what we have first AMT gearboxes never really smooth not the best experience but if anyone does AMD is better it is maruti and this is the most refined version they have so if you drive it in a sedate manner it's the downshifting if the car is at fifth gear cruising around 60 70 kph if you push if you see an opportunity to overtake just a little legs and it drops down to third or even second in some cases and course it's lost that swiftness of the older gen but it still is nice and linear you know you don't really feel like it's a lethargic engine it doesn't have that pep in the second half of the Rev range but from the bottom end it is nice and responsive and that is where you really appreciate it in City driving in that 20 to 40 20 to 60 area that is when the engine has a good amount of Pep to it while the needle does REV freely to the red line performance is gradual and you get a sense that this is not an engine you want to push especially with an AMT but we also sampled the manual to see if that helps the is for [Applause] [Music] enthusiasts now the manual gearbox on the Swift desire nice light clutch and quite Progressive as well but if you're expecting this car to be fun to drive experience of course you have a a bit better control over the power because the gearbox is not trying to upshift as soon as possible like the AMT shifts are nice and light as well the gears slot in very easily and even in traffic it's not going to be too much of a pain because the clutch as I mentioned is very light but with the manual gearbox is where you feel a bit of that lack in power a bit more power would have definitely transform this whole car in terms of the tune both the Swift and the desire share the same gearing and and engine mapping as well what's changed slightly is the suspension tune to compensate for the added weight for the desire ride quality is also very good the suspension is nice and soft so bad patches broken roads marui knows exactly how they are in our country and the tuning is done in the same way despite the added weight and the added bit at the rear it still feels nice and soft and given the soft seats the overall Comfort is quite good and speaking of on the handling the steering is nice and light again nothing really sporty about it tight Corners you will have a fair bit of under steer if you push it but apart from that everyday maneuvering is very easy the steering feels fluid and consistent and tight turns are dealt with ease we couldn't do an efficiency test on a short drive but mati claims 24.7 kpl for the manual and 25.7 kpl for the AMT for those who want even more desire also gets the option of a CNG with the 5-speed manual gearbox which claims 33.7 km per kg the full test figures will be out as soon as we get our hands on the car for a longer [Music] duration prices for the desire start at 6.79 lak rupees and go till 10.14 lakh rupees for the top spec AMT variant the CG starts at 8.74 lak rupees for the vxi and 9.84 lakh for the ZXI trim with the manual gearbox this makes it competitive against his Rivals when it comes to manual versions but the most expensive in the segment with an AMT what maruti has done with the new desire is give it a new identity with new sharp looks added features bright upholstry and the extra practicality it has all the right ingredients to pull in the crowd and continue on as maruti's bestselling sedan [Music]

videos.transcript:
Should I go for a hatchback or a sedan? Let's find out. First, let's get this out of the way: both cars come with the same key, and the color is not even different. You get lock and unlock buttons on both. The only difference is that the Dzire's key has an additional button to open the boot, which, when pressed, not only unlocks the boot but opens it completely. However, if we just look at the keys, they are quite old-fashionedâ€”small, lightweight plastic keys with a glossy finish on one side, and their design is quite basic.

Speaking of design, let's start with the Dzire. I find it to be decent, and then comes the Swift, whose design you might prefer more. Between the two, I think the Dzire looks better because its design is simpler and more subdued. It has more horizontal elements, and the headlamp is sleeker. The Swift looks more modern and larger, but most importantly, it now starts at â‚¹500,000, which is a bit of a budget concern. Now, which car do you prefer between the two? Let us know in the comments.

Next up is boot space. Here, the Dzire is clearly better due to its body style. The Dzire's boot space is more generous, and the dashboard and doors have textured materials, while the steering wheel and center console feature a gloss black finish to show that this car is almost â‚¹1 million. The fit and finish are similar to what you'd expect from any other Maruti Suzuki. Just imagine if this black had red inserts; it would have looked much more appealing. Right now, it looks more sporty than premium, and if you want a sporty look for your car, one drawback is that the seats get dirty very quickly and require a lot of effort to keep clean.

Now, there is a gray strip on the dashboard, but there is also a wooden finish included. Now, if you've spent â‚¹500,000 extra, you would expect a few more features, right? In the Dzire, you get two or three extra features: a single-pane sunroof, a tire pressure monitoring system, and a 360Â° camera. The sunroof isn't that useful; it depends on your preference, but the camera is definitely useful if you're trying to maneuver out of a tight parking space or a narrow lane. Other than that, the features are the same in both cars. You get a 9-inch touchscreen with a simple interface and large icons, making it easy for older family members to use. Both have a wireless Android Auto charger, adjustable power mirrors, auto AC, push-button start/stop, and auto headlamps.

In terms of safety, besides the 360Â° camera and tire pressure monitoring system, there are no changes. Both cars come with six standard airbags, ABS with EBD, electronic stability control, ISOFIX child seat anchors, and hill hold assist. The Swift doesn't have a camera, but it does come with a rearview camera with guidelines. One more thing: the Dzire has a five-star safety rating from Global NCAP, while Maruti's tests for Global NCAP or Bharat NCAP are not available, so we won't know until then.

Next is practicality, and the tone will change here. Storage and charging options are almost the same in both cars. All four doors have 1-liter bottle holders, and the Swift has 500ml holders. You get two cup holders at the front, a glove box, and seat back pockets behind the front passenger seat in both cars. The Dzire has an additional rear seat center armrest with two cup holders. For charging, both cars have a wireless phone charger, a 12-volt socket, a USB port, and a Type-C port for rear passengers, along with rear AC vents.

Now let's talk about space. Starting with the rear, it is sufficient for three, with good headroom, and there are no issues with knee room and foot room. The under-thigh support is also decent. The rear seat's recline angle is good, so you can sit comfortably on long rides. However, there is no center armrest, which would have obviously made the rear seat experience more comfortable. The dark theme of the cabin gives a cramped feeling, and the larger headrests reduce visibility. So, while space is sufficient for two people, the rear seat experience could have been better, as it is in the Dzire.

Here, the space is similar, and despite the sloping roofline, headroom is sufficient. Yes, the Swift also accommodates taller individuals. Speaking of visibility, it is also better due to the cabin lights, which give a better sense of space, and the sunroof lets in more light, improving visibility.

Now that we've covered the differences between these two cars, before moving to the verdict, let's look at their driving experience. Both cars have the same engine and transmission options, and their tuning is also the same, which is better for city drives. Both come with a 1.2-liter three-cylinder petrol engine, which feels slightly less powerful and not as refined as before, meaning you will feel some vibrations in the footwell while driving, but they are not enough to be irritating. Power delivery is smooth, and even though the power is less, city drives are significantly better, giving you an easy mileage of 17 to 18 km/l, and on the highway, around 20-21 km/l.

The Dzire comes with a manual transmission, and in first gear, the power feels a bit low, requiring you to stay on the clutch, but the tuning in second gear is quite good. It's so good that you can easily reach speeds of 80-85 km/h in this gear without straining the engine, making it easy to drive in the city without feeling a lack of power or needing to change gears frequently.

Now, let's talk about the Swift. In the Swift, you will take time to reach high speeds, especially if you're accelerating from 70-80 km/h to 100 km/h; the acceleration feels slow, and you will have to plan your overtakes. Overall, you will feel a lack of power in the highway experience. Both cars have lost some of their sporty feel, but they have become better for city driving. So, I guess you have to lose something to gain something, but you won't lose comfort in either car. At city speeds, small potholes are easily absorbed, and you won't feel any sudden jerks inside the car. Yes, you will notice road cracks more, but it doesn't lead to discomfort. Rear seat passengers will also be comfortable in both cars. The cabin's movement is well controlled, and you won't feel any sudden body movements inside the car. However, on highways, both cars can be quite jumpy, and at high speeds, even small potholes will cause noticeable body movement. It's better to keep them slow on highway connections and flyover joints to avoid jolts, but rear passengers will face significant body movement.

When it comes to handling, both cars feel planted in corners, making them fun to drive. But if I had to pick one, I would lean towards the Swift. 

In conclusion, I think the Dzire easily justifies its â‚¹50,000 price premium due to its better cabin, additional features, and improved safety. Anyway, after financing, the monthly difference will only be â‚¹1,000. So, if you're looking for a complete family car in this budget, we recommend the Dzire. If you want the Swift, yes, the Dzire is definitely the better car overall, but whether its benefits are useful to you is something you'll have to decide. I hope you liked the video. Like, comment, subscribe, and check out more videos and other cars. Bye!

videos.transcript: [Music] Welcome to car and bike. I am Sean Vijay Ragun and this is the Maruti Suzuki Desire. It is one of the bestselling cars in India and it has been part of the car and bike garage for about 6 months now. It is now time for the car to head back to its home. But before that I wanted to share how is it to live with the desire which is also Bauti's top seller. Now there are some pros, there are some cons and a lot in between. So if you are new to the channel do subscribe to carbike and hit that bell notification as well so you never miss an update like this and videos that we make for you. Now the desire has been in the market for several years now and this particular car is the fourth generation avar of the subcompact sedan and compared to the first generation model the desire has come a long way. It now looks more proportionate welldesigned and well styled. You get a proper size. Now this is not a threebox sedan but you still have that look over here with a boot with a glass area and a proper bonnet but it also looks nice. Now you have LED lighting all across. You also get alloy wheels that look particularly nice in this dual tone avar. And it is well sized for the city. So it's easier to maneuver around in traffic and those small lanes we see in cities like Mumbai and Delhi. And also it is stable enough for the highways because I have taken this car from Mumbai to Goa and I had no issues in terms of its size and capabilities. But more on that when we are driving the car. But overall, I think that the Desire is well sized for a city car. Now, like the exterior, the cabin of the Desire 2 has evolved over the years, and I can say that right now, the Desire's cabin is probably one of its best so far. Now, here you get a lot of textures and design that it has a modern appeal to it. This 9-in touchscreen infotainment system adds a bit of uh futuristic look to the car. You also get automatic AC. So yes, feature- wise it is quite packed. But what it lacks is a sense of premiumness. You see that while the textures and the design are nice. The use of plastic quality, the PL the materials used here are not of the best quality. H they could have been better. Uh even this fourwood treatment is not the best. So it could have been something a bit more premium. Uh you also get these seats. Now I have a big problem with these seats. You can see that these are fabric seat covers. Uh Maruti could have gone with four leather for the top of the line at least. But yes, here even in this particular top end model you get fabric seats and these are quite uh white and they get dirty. You can see that this car is already dirty. Uh this is not something that happened by us. This was this came in this uh way. So yes uh it will quick get dirty quickly and you have to take that into account. Also an issue for me is the ergonomics of the car. You see that there is no central armrest for the driver and I feel it is a very important feature to have that adds a bit of comfort level that is missing in the desire. You get it in some of the big other Marikas like francs but here it is missing. While the seats do offer support cushioning could have been better. they are a bit on the thinner side and while it's good enough for everyday commute or short drives, long drives will be a challenge. My advice would be to get some nice quality aftermarket seat covers with some padding. Apart from that, the space is good. You can have uh four to five adults sitting here. Yes, the second row uh having three adults will be a tight squeeze, but it won't be very uncomfortable. It will be okay for short journeys, but for four adults, it is a nice car. It is spacious enough and no wonder the desire has been a big choice for Indian buyers who are looking for a family sedan. [Music] Now with this fourth generation Desire, you get a lot of features that were never offered with this car before and some of these features are something that you did not expect that Maroti will offer with the Desire. This includes a big 9-in touchscreen infotainment system. You get uh both wireless Apple CarPlay and Android Auto and the connection is also quite seamless. Uh you also get a wireless phone charger now so you can charge your phone without the cables. There is a sunroof as well. This is an electric single pens unit but for the size of the car this is quite ideal. Then you have a 360deree view camera which I feel is a very important feature and especially for a city car which is a city family car uh considering uh we have narrow roads and small parking spots in cities like Mumbai uh it comes in great help and uh it is a good feature. In fact the quality of the 360Â° view camera of the desire is also quite nice. These are features that elevate the Desire's appeal. And if you can look past some of the negatives of the cabin like the quality of plastics and the seat covers, then the Desire is a very nice car to have. The Desire has managed to put the stereotype to rest that Maruti Suzuki cars are not safe because they get low safety ratings. The car has bagged five-star rating both from Global Encap as well as Bhat Ncap. Being the first Maruti Suzuki car to do that. Every trim gets six airbags, electronic stability control, seat belt, pre-tensioners and ISOIX mounts. So yes, if safety rating is important to you, the Desire safety package brings real peace of mind. Now, there are a lot of things to love about the Desire, especially when you're driving it, but uh I have to say that this engine might not be one of them for me especially. Well, you see, it produces almost the same amount of power and torque as the previous generation model which came with a four-cylinder engine whereas this is a three port engine. It's a new engine. Yes. Uh and it produces almost the same amount of power and output. Uh but uh it is not as refined as the previous motor. It is also not as peppy. Well uh this engine works nicely in the Swift which is a smaller car. Uh but in the desire it feels sluggish. It feels a bit underpowered and not that uh fun to drive in essence. So yes, it will do the job but it is nothing that will make you want to get behind the wheel again and again. I like the car's ride quality. It feels supple. It It takes on all the undulations on the road quite nicely and also it handles really well. Uh it is nimble so easy to maneuver around the city and uh that will not be an issue. The steering is light. Yes, a bit too light for my liking but great if you are driving in uh stop and go traffic and you you encounter traffic on a day-to-day basis then this is a boon for you. Now the desire comes in both manual as well as AMT option and owing to the nature of the engine. I feel that uh I prefer the manual version more because there I have more control. I can engage with the car more and uh that adds a bit of uh driving pleasure for me. However, if you want something more smoother uh in terms of drivability, you want something that is hassle-free, then the AMT option makes a lot of sense. And uh if that is something that you want from your drive then you should go for it. In terms of fuel efficiency, Maruti Suzuki claims that the desire can return a little over 25 km to the litter both in the manual as well as the AMT. Uh yes, in a real perfect scenario where you get the ideal driving conditions, you can achieve somewhere around that. But uh on an average, realistically speaking, the Desire will offer you a mileage of anywhere between 18 to 20 km to the litter on the highway. And in the city, you can possibly go down as low as 15 to 17 km to the litter. And those are very good numbers. And uh I'll tell you that uh I drove this car down from Mumbai to Goa and I did about 530 or 540 odd kilometers one way and I did it in one single tank and that is saying something. The Maruti Suzuki Desire is offered in four key variants LXI, VXI, ZXI and ZXI Plus. And depending on the trim, transmission, and fuel option, you have nine different choices, including a factory fitted CNG option, which is available in two variants. [Applause] Now, after spending 6 months with the Desire, I can say that the Desire is not about thrills. It is about reliability. It is about frugality and it is about ease of use. Now it is a practical car through and through and with all the features and tech on offer that Maruti is offering with this fourth gener it will also attract the modern-day car buyer. Now there are some negatives as well like uh the quality of plastics and the seating material is average and the engine is a bit underwhelming but you also have to think about the fact that the engine is also very frugal. So though overall the desire is not that expensive. So, it is affordable to buy. It will not be heavy on your pocket to maintain. And the fuel efficiency is something that you can live with in this modern-day fuel prices. Overall, it is a great pick for the firsttime car buyer or budget conscious families. So, what do you think about the Desire? Let us know in the comments. If you have any questions or queries about the car, you mention them in the comments and we will try to answer them. And if you like this video, do give it a thumbs up and share it with your friends. And for more such videos, keep following carbike.

videos.transcript: You truly get to know them once you start living with them. No, no, wait. This is not about humans, but cars. I've been living with a particular car for over 3 months now. A car which has become a household name by now. A brand in itself. And I'm talking about the allnew Marauti Suzuki Desire. [Music] The Desire's top-of-the-line ZXI Plus and the AMT guys came to the car wireless table in late December and I have been daily driving it since then. With over 5,000 km already clocked on the auto, I have plenty of things to talk about. The good, the not so good, the features that make sense, sensible features which have given a miss, the real world fuel efficiency figures, and the most important thing, can you actually live with one? Well, I'll try to cover everything. So stick around till the end. My name is and you are watching Car Walle. [Music] [Applause] [Music] Choosing the right variant is quite easy as there are not a lot of them. That's just four LXI, VXI, ZXI, and ZXI Plus. This one we have here is a topsp spec ZXI plus in petrol AMT guys. I am specifying petrol because the CG option 2 with the VXI and ZXI variants. Now, as for the prices, the desire continues to be in the affordable price bracket. Currently, the compact sedan is available at a starting extra room cost of rupes 6.84 lakh. Meanwhile, the one right here will cost you rupes 10.20 lakh without the taxes. [Music] So without wasting any more time, let's quickly get to the positives and see what makes the new gen Maruti Suzuki Desire a compelling option. The Desire has always been the car for the masses. I mean the brand has never focused on the features at least with this one, but that has definitely changed with the new gen. This one is loaded and how I mean there's a lot of mouthy bits here from the swift breza and even the baleno. Well, it gets a 9-in infotainment screen which runs on a very simple yet very functional UI. I mean there's wireless Android Auto and Apple CarPlay connectivity and it connects instantly the moment you get in the wireless Apple CarPlay just connects automatically and the maps are displayed very in a very detailed manner. Also, one thing is also interesting. You can uh see the real world or the onboard navigation in the mid screen using the Apple maps on, of course, the Apple CarPlay. However, there's one thing that I don't like about the infotainment is the bezel around it. I mean, it could have been a lot slimmer because that doesn't add any purpose. It's just massive and a chunky piece of plastic. When you are driving, you look at it. Other than that, there are other features like this 360Â° camera. There's electric sunroof, the three-point seat belt, high adjustable driver seat. Also, there's a wireless charger and thankfully you can also turn it off, which is a good thing because it charges your phone very slow and the phone heats up. I personally don't use it, but again, having an option is a very good thing. Well, this is an important one. After constantly facing backlash for the safety aspect, Marauti has finally changed how their cars is seen. Well, this one right here is a five-star GNC cap rated car, and it has a lot of safety features going for it. ABS with DVD, brake assist, hill hold control, 360Â° camera, six airbags, and most importantly, seat belt reminder with a warning, but with load sensors, and in a big safety update, the new Desire has now also proudly received a five-star safety rating from Bharat Ncap, building on its five-star global endcap success. [Music] Another positive aspect is the new Z series engine. Yes, it lacks a cylinder, but hear me out. It gets a 1.2 L N petrol engine paired with AMT gearbox and a 5-speed manual gearbox. In this combination, the AMT version, it is a perfect balance between the performance and efficiency, and the engine really feels good. While this motor is tuned to generate 80 bhp and 111 mm of peak torque. Now, this new Z series engine feels smooth and refined, and it is quite zesty for most of the part. Not as not quick right off the bat, but once you hit the sweet spot of 2,00 to 2,500 RPM, it is it feels lively. The acceleration is smooth. The gearbox, the AMD gearbox feels perfectly balanced, and it doesn't feel jerky at all. I mean, the gear shifts are not exactly unnoticeable, but it is not unpleasant as well. Apart from that, the sharing is lightweight. The controls are easy. The overall lightweight nature of the car itself make it quite easy to maneuver. For example, this turn here is going to be extremely easy. So from lock to lock, it is 3.5 turns. Apart from that, the ride quality is pleasant. I mean the suspension is slight perfectly tuned. Uh now it shares a platform with the Swift which is slightly which has slightly stiffer suspension. This one has a very comfortable ride quality. The suspensions are tuned it to be for a family car unlike Swift. It feels much more tighter compared to this. Other than that the overall ride quality is good for the front seats and for the back seats. Now coming to the visibility part, the pillars are marginally thin and the glass area, the window area is good. The overall visibility be from the IRVM, the OVMs are pretty big and it's quite easy to look out for obstacles and overall the vision is great with this car. That said, the braking could have been better. I mean it is progressive though but there's no rear disc brakes so that could have been better. Also with the 163 mm ground clearance I never faced any issue over the 3 months I have been using this. There's no potholes or road andulation that you know felt inside the cabin due to sharp nature. Also the NVH could have been better. I mean this is a con which I'll talk about later. But yeah, the NVS the engine current is it filters inside the cabin insulation is something which Mari could have worked on with this one. Again, this could be a characteristic of a three-cylinder engine compared to a four-cylinder one. The vibrations could be felt at the pedal and the steering wheel also on the gear knob, but again, not something very unpleasant. And for the final segment of positives, we have kept of course the mileage figures, the real world mileage figures of the Marauti Suzuki Desire. We did an extensive caral style mileage test of the Marauti Suzuki Desire and the figures are rather good. So talking about the mileage, we did real world mileage test and in our results in city, the car returned 14.1 km per liter. Meanwhile on highway, the number went up to 19.42 km per liter. This being an AMT version, of course, the manual maybe would give better efficiency depending on your driving style. However, in my daily commute, I've been extracting 16 to 17 km per liter on an average in scenarios including highway and city as well. So, overall, I'm pretty satisfied with the mileage of the new gen Desire. Now that we are done with the positives, let's quickly glance over the underwhelming aspects of the Marauti Suzuki Desire. Now, don't get me wrong, the Desire gets plenty of handful features, but there are a few features it still lacks which could have made more sense. Firstly, these seats are fabric white upholstery and they get dirty easily and it is equally hard to keep them clean. Also, the front seats are not ventilated. then the driver doesn't get an amish at all even though this is the top-of-the-line ZXI plus AMT version. So that could have been a boon to drivers. And finally, this is sort of nitpicking, but an auto dimming IRVM would have made more sense, but this is again a manual IRVM day and night. The NVH and overall cabin insulation could have been better. I mean the plastic quality or rather the material quality again is slightly underwhelming compared to its major rival the Honda Amaze which gets slightly better material quality. About that we have done an extensive comparison between the Honda Amaze and the Maroti Suzuki Desire. So head to our channel to watch that video. [Music] Well, there's a very subtle way for me to conclude what I feel about the new Maruti Suzuki Desire. I mean, the name plate itself is enough for it to continue selling like a hot cake. And with the latest update, it is much more easier for me to recommend it to more customers. There's hardly anything that I hate about it. I mean, look at it. It is a well sorted, nononsense car for a family of four who's looking for a car option to buy with a low service cost, hassle-free ownership experience, reliability, and also good fuel efficiency. I mean, Maruti has just got the recipe right. I personally enjoyed spending most of my time with this one for over past few months now. Be the daily commute of over 50 kilometers, weekend getaways with friends. Hell, I've also used it to move my house around. So indeed, it has kept me happy for the last few months and I think there's no incident that has made me question its reliability. So that's it. This was the video guys. I mean if you have any question related to the Marauti Suzuki Desire or any other car, the comment sections is open. My name is and you are watching Carwali. [Music]

videos.transcript:
I have had this Dzire for the last 6 months, and here are three things I really like about it and three things I donâ€™t. The design of the Dzire has evolved over the last four generations. It looks more proportionate, stylish, and comes with a lot of fancy features. For instance, you get LED lighting, LED DRLs, LED tail lamps, and sporty dual-tone alloys. The new Dzire is quite feature-packed. According to modern car standards, it comes with a 9-inch touchscreen infotainment system, a wireless phone charger, a 360Â° view camera, and even a sunroof. The Dzire is thoroughly a practical car. It's affordable, easy to maintain, and very fuel-efficient. In fact, the company claims that whether it's the manual or AMT variant, you can achieve a mileage of 25 kmpl with this car. During my testing, I noticed that in the city, it comfortably delivers an average of 16 to 18 kmpl, and on the highway, it can realistically give you 20 kmpl or more.

Now, talking about the negatives, I have a slight issue with the fit and finish of the Dzire. The styling is quite good, with nice textures and paneling, but the quality of the plastic used is not top-notch. It feels a bit average. Even in the top-end variant, you will find fabric seats, which are also in a light color. There are no options for darker colors, so they will stain quite quickly. I also have some problems with the ergonomics of the Dzire. There is no central armrest, so there is no space to rest your arm, and I think this is an important feature. On long drives, this can induce fatigue. It was quite important to have that here. I also didnâ€™t find the seating position very comfortable. I am 5 feet 9 inches tall, and finding a perfect ideal seating position according to my size and stretch is a bit challenging. I have noticed that I experience some pain in my upper shoulder during long drives, so getting the perfect seating position is somewhat difficult.

The Dzire comes with a 1.2 L petrol engine. It is a three-cylinder motor. Previously, you had a four-cylinder motor, which felt more refined, smoother, and peppier. Here, while the Dzire's engine gives similar output, it feels sluggish, which I didnâ€™t like much. Finally, there is a stigma that the Dzire is a taxi, but with this new generation model, the company has included many modern features that make it feel like a modern-day car. However, the company had stated at the launch that this new generation Dzire would not be offered for the taxi segment. Yet, within a few months of the launch, you might have seen this new Dzire in taxis as well. So, this might not sit well with some buyers.
